replies.text: Your table is missing a key piece of data, analysts usually give 12 month price targets, so how accurate did the analysts price turn out to be 12 months later? Also some websites chart out in a graph both what the analysts average price target was, and where the stocks price went overtime. When you do this for some stocks, like T for example, it shows that analysts consistently call it pretty undervalued, and yet the stock also consistently under performs the market andor loses value. By your logic stocks like T would have been a good buy, even though history shows that you would have lost a lot of money in it. On the flipside meanwhile stocks like NFLX and TSLA would have been called dreadful and highly overvalued investments by analysts at various points, when it was actually the best time to buy those supposedly overpriced stocks.
Every single one of those is a tech company, you shouldnt have your whole portfolio in 1 sector
If youre interested in this style of analysis you might enjoy Tipranks.
Interesting. I kind of want to track this and see if it pans out.
Analysts ratings and price targets are absolutely useless information

Usually stock trading below target for a long period of time is a sign of consistent earning downward adjustment, meaning a stock is failing expectation either slower growth or negative growth QoQ. If the company is good, it will eventually go back on growth track like Chipotle and Eli Lilly or like McDonalds or Nike, it needs some serious stock picking skill and long time observing the industrial trend.
AMD is really interesting. One of the lowest percent to price target but 031 analysts rated it as even a buy.

He put intel target at 38

Ill be honest its really not. I came to knowast year that NVDA was priced above 700 pre split but I was scared and only invested in QQQM. It then crossed 1000. I read about analyst ratings about ISRG. I invested a small amount after some research. It has gone 20 since then and has been solid despite tech sell off. I think analyst ratings is helpful to screen companies and not go tits up. I think what is usually lost is that they give a price range and typically most of us dont take risk into account and just invest blindly.
Its a site where they aggregate analyst price targets for a large number of stocks. They keep track of how accurate each analyst is for a specific stock so you get a sense of who you should follow.

Its called momentum, you rode a trade that everyone was on and it kept rising just like when Tesla was hit before and other stocks before they stagnate or decline. Analysts are also chasing the hype since very few had 700 upside target on Nvidia before it tripled they keep adjusting depending on the flowtrend
All analysts literally do is move their price targets as the stock goes up and down. It literally is useless information

Not true. Take a look at stock OTGLY. Its video game company CD Project. It has gone up 40 in last 3 months. Yet I researched and 8 analysts think it is a sell and 4 say it is a buy. I still invested because I follow the company and think there is a significant upside and current analyst opinions are recency bias. So I believe analyst opinions are a piece of information. If you blindly follow then you might get burned but using their opinion as a piece of information to screen stocks is valuable.
If analysts truly had a crystal ball why the hell would they give such valuable information away for free?

Agreed. There are also good and bad analysts. I often read reports even from what I consider good services and shake my head at times when its a field I know a lot about. To reiterate, Its a data point. If all the analysts predict a thing even if its wrong it will affect prices.

... They dont. Analysts get paid. And they are supposed to give honest projections. Its not some scam like you guys believe it is. They research the companies, speak to insiders and try to project where the stock price will be in 12 months. They can be spot on with revenue and earnings projections and still be way off on the stock price. Thats the stock market

No one has crystal ball. Again I find it is useful to screen stocks. To follow their arguments for prices. Regarding other question I agree that it cant be 100 right. But some of the opinions are behind paywall. But you still get to see the consensus buysellhold. Also some banks etc are publicly traded right? So they have to be atleast somewhat open about their investments and cant just make shit up. Again we need to do our own research at the end of the day.

I mean analyst is not a protected job description so there is a range, but yes real analysts are good at analyzing the businesses. That the stock market is highly regarded makes share price harder to gauge.
I just find that 90 of analysts follow momentum. Very few of them go against the crowd. Thus their opinions matter very little

I cut the cable in 2008 when my cablesatellite bill was above 300month not to mention the cost of the receivers. I couldnt justify 300mo for the volume and percentage of commercials I was forced to watch on live TV. My first streaming device was my Wii console and ultimately moved to Roku. Ive been an A La Carte viewer since and am still paying significantly less monthly than I was in 2008, and, unless I need to watch live News or an urgent Weather broadcast Im happy to watch my favorite shows a day or a month, season or year after the networks broadcast live. While I dont subscribe to Disney, Im a Hulu, Amazon Prime, Netflix, YouTube premium, Pandora premium, Paramount with Showtime Peacock commercial free, Apple TV subscriber. The bottom line is I never run out of commercial free great movies, series, shows, documentaries, music, concerts, and global news to watch at my leisure and schedule in addition, my two kids and grandchild can watch pretty much whatever they love commercial free for significantly less than a commercial dominated satellite or cable broadcast which require a subscription for the better and best content anyway Im not a big sports aficionado, so I dont subscribe to the NFL or MLB streams, but know enough people to watch a game with if I really want to. When you get used to watching what you want without constant commercial interruptions, it becomes very difficult and annoying to watch commercials every few minutes. At least for me.
Thats peace of mind, if nothing else

There are two narratives in play: GenAI upstarts will eat Adobe's lunch (e.g. the reaction to OpenAI's Sora earlier this year, which IMHO was a Generative Mechanical Turk with Pixar inside the cabinet), or Adobe will eat the upstarts' lunch(es). The demos from the upstarts are one-off creations and you can take your pick at who is "better" at text-to-image or text-to-video. Adobe is being more subtle and going after the entire creative/editorial workflow. Not as sexy and harder to explain, but it is where the proverbial rubber meets the road. Another poster to this board has noted that October is tax-loss harvesting season for funds, and Adobe fits the bill (it is down). The narrative is likely to change in Adobe's favor in 2025, when it delivers GenAI related revenue and an uptick in growth, in which case twelve months from now it won't be a TLC (tax loss candidate), because it will likely be up YTD and a momentum/growth play. This is not the first time Adobe has reinvented itself in response to rapid technological change -- recall the transition to SaaS subscription models where Adobe had to weather a short-term decline in GAAP revenue (upfront license revenue switching to monthly subscription) and educate analysts about ARR, which was tough, but the company came out smiling. Meanwhile there is another hypothesis being tested: Did the FTC (and European authorities) actually do Adobe a favor by deep-sixing the Figma acquisition? You can place your bets.

Assuming there's no news, here's my explanation for today's price action in ADBE: tax-loss selling. Most mutual funds sell in October to harvest tax-losses. Based on an analysis by Bank of America, the top Tax Loss Candidates ("TLCs") are stocks that are down by 10% YTD. ADBE, unfortunately, qualifies. Mutual funds sell TLCs in October and start buying back after a month has passed. Here's the good news: According to the same analysis from Bank of America, stocks that are tax loss candidates (TLCs) have historically outperformed the stock market from November through January by an average of 1.9% since January 1986 through January 2023.
See my comment below on tax loss selling. Bank of America has a good analysis on this. Stocks are sold for tax reasons in October, outperform the S&P 500 in the Nov-Jan period.
